best-practice.name: one and only one title
best-practice.rule: The page must contain exactly one title element.

best-practice.name: number of empty title elements
best-practice.rule: The title element must have text content.

best-practice.name: at least one h1 element
best-practice.rule: The page must contain at least one h1 element.

best-practice.name: no more than two h1 elements
best-practice.rule: The page should contain no more than two h1 elements.

best-practice.name: h1 substring of title
best-practice.rule: The text content of each h1 element should match all or part of the title content.
best-practice.info: The matching algorithm for this rule includes the alt text of any img elements the h1 may contain, and ignores case, punctuation and spacing in the text content of the title and h1 elements.

best-practice.name: number of empty h1 elements, including img alt text
best-practice.rule: Each h1 element must have text content.
best-practice.info: If an img element with an alt attribute is contained in an h1 element, the alt attribute value is inserted in document order into the text content of the h1 element.

best-practice.name: number of empty h1 elements, excluding img alt text
best-practice.rule: Each h1 element should have text content exclusive of the alt text of any img elements it contains.

best-practice.name: proper nesting of heading elements
best-practice.rule: Subheading elements that follow the last h1 should be properly nested.
best-practice.info: Subheading elements should be used without skipping levels when descending through the sublevels h2..h6. For example, an h2 element should follow an h1 element, an h3 element should follow an h2 element, and so on. Note that this rule does not apply to subheadings of the same level (for example, an h3 may follow another h3), or when ascending the hierarchy (an h2 may follow an h4).

best-practice.name: number of empty heading elements, including alt text
best-practice.rule: Each subheading element (h2..h6) must have text content.
best-practice.info: If an img element with an alt attribute is contained in a subheading element, the alt attribute value is inserted in document order into the text content of the subheading element.

best-practice.name: number of empty heading elements, excluding alt text
best-practice.rule: Each subheading element (h2..h6) should have text content exclusive of the alt text of any img elements it contains.

best-practice.name: ul/ol navigation menus
best-practice.rule: Each ul or ol element that precedes the last h1 element and appears to be a navigation bar should be immediately preceded by a heading element, preferably an h2.
best-practice.info: FAE considers a ul or ol element to be a navigation bar if it appears to be a navigation list, defined recursively as follows. A navigation list is a ul or ol element that contains one or more "item with link" li elements, and no more than one li element that does not qualify as an "item with link". An "item with link" is defined as an li element that contains either a single text link (a element) or a link followed by a nested navigation list, optionally preceded by a heading element.

best-practice.name: map navigation bars
best-practice.rule: Each map element that precedes the last h1 element and appears to be a navigation bar should be immediately preceded by a heading element, preferably an h2
best-practice.info: FAE considers a map element to be a navigation bar if it contains one or more area elements.

best-practice.name: redundant text links for area elements
best-practice.rule: Each area element should have a redundant text link (a element) with matching href value.

best-practice.name: form control labels for select, textarea and input elements
best-practice.rule: Each input element with type=text | password | checkbox | radio | file and each select and textarea element must either be referenced by the for attribute of a label element via its id attribute, or have a title attribute.
best-practice.info: Label referencing is implemented by setting the label element's for attribute value equal to that of the form control's id attribute.

best-practice.name: form control labels for input elements with type=button|reset|submit
best-practice.rule: Each input element with type=button | submit | reset must have either a value attribute or a title attribute.

best-practice.name: form control labels for input elements with type=image
best-practice.rule: Each input element with type=image must have either an alt attribute or a title attribute.

best-practice.name: label and legend elements must not be empty
best-practice.rule: Each label and legend element must have text content.

best-practice.name: html@lang attribute
best-practice.rule: Each page must have a lang attribute on its html element whose value or initial subtag is a valid two-character language code.
best-practice.info: Valid two-character language codes are defined in the IANA Language Subtag Registry. If the lang attribute value is hyphenated, then the substring preceding the first hyphen is tested for validity.

best-practice.name: data table must use th in first cell of all columns or rows
best-practice.rule: Each data table must utilize th elements as the first cells of all columns or rows.

best-practice.name: each data table must have summary attribute
best-practice.rule: Each data table must have a nonempty summary attribute.

best-practice.name: unique summary attribute values on data tables
best-practice.rule: The summary attribute value for each data table on a page should be unique.
best-practice.info: Uniqueness comparisons are case-insensitive and performed on whitespace-normalized attribute values.

best-practice.name: accesskey values should be unique
best-practice.rule: Each accesskey attribute value on a page should be unique.

best-practice.name: nonempty frame titles
best-practice.rule: Each frame element must have a nonempty title attribute.

best-practice.name: unique frame titles
best-practice.rule: The title attribute value for each frame element within a frameset must be unique.
best-practice.info: Uniqueness comparisons are case-insensitive and performed on whitespace-normalized attribute values.

best-practice.name: images with alt attribute
best-practice.rule: Each img element must have an alt attribute.

best-practice.name: images with alt text
best-practice.rule: Each img element with an empty alt attribute should be removed; CSS techniques should be used instead.

best-practice.name: images with width or height less than 8 pixels
best-practice.rule: Each img element with width or height less than 8 pixels should be removed; CSS techniques should be used instead.

best-practice.name: area elements with alt attribute
best-practice.rule: Each area element must have an alt attribute.

best-practice.name: onclick actions on nonfocusable elements
best-practice.rule: The onclick attribute should not be used on elements that cannot accept keyboard focus.

best-practice.name: onmouseover and onfocus actions on focusable elements
best-practice.rule: Each focusable element with an onmouseover attribute must also have an onfocus attribute, and their associated event handlers should trigger the same or similar actions.
best-practice.info: Focusable elements are primarily links and form controls. Specifically, they include the a element with an href attribute and/or a tabindex attribute with a value of 0 or greater, and the area, button, input, select and textarea elements.

best-practice.name: onmouseout and onblur actions on focusable elements
best-practice.rule: Each focusable element with an onmouseout attribute must also have an onblur attribute, and their associated event handlers should trigger the same or similar actions.
best-practice.info: Focusable elements are primarily links and form controls. Specifically, they include the a element with an href attribute and/or a tabindex attribute with a value of 0 or greater, and the area, button, input, select and textarea elements.

best-practice.name: onmouseover and onmouseout actions on nonfocusable elements
best-practice.rule: The onmouseover and onmouseout attributes should not be used on elements that cannot accept keyboard focus; use CSS techniques instead to provide the desired stylistic effects.

best-practice.name: inline style elements: font and center
best-practice.rule: The font and center elements must not be used. Instead use structural markup with CSS for styling.

best-practice.name: inline style elements: b
best-practice.rule: The b element must not be used for bold styling of text content. Instead use heading elements h1..h6 for heading text or the strong element for emphasizing words, phrases or sentences.

best-practice.name: inline style elements: i
best-practice.rule: The i element must not be used to italicize text content. Instead use heading elements h1..h6 for heading text or the em element for emphasizing words, phrases or sentences.

best-practice.name: inline style elements: u
best-practice.rule: The u element must not be used to underline text content. Instead use heading elements h1..h6 for heading text or the em or strong elements for emphasizing words, phrases or sentences.

best-practice.name: inline style elements: blink and marquee
best-practice.rule: The blink and marquee elements must not be used.
best-practice.info: Blinking or moving text causes accessibility problems for people with photosenstive epilepsy and visual impairments.

best-practice.name: tables for positioning & layout
best-practice.rule: Tables should be used only for organizing data in rows and columns. Use CSS instead of tables and nested tables to visually layout blocks of related content for graphical rendering.
best-practice.info: The existence of deeply nested tables suggests that tables are being used for page layout. Nested tables can cause readability problems when a page is linearized.

best-practice.name: DOCTYPE declaration
best-practice.rule: Each page must include a DOCTYPE declaration to facilitate rendering and validation.

best-practice.name: character encoding decl.
best-practice.rule: The character encoding of each page should be specified within the value of the content attribute (using charset=) on a meta element that also includes an http-equiv attribute set to "content-type".
best-practice.info: For example, if the character encoding is UTF-8, it could be specified in XHTML with: <meta http-equiv="content-type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8"/>
